body_text.text: The Permian nonmarine strata of Texas have yielded significant coprolite ichnofaunas in addition to the better known vertebrate body fossils (Neumayer, 1904; Hunt et al., 1988; Hunt and Lucas, 2005a, b) . Some complete and fragmentary coprolites are over 12 cm in length. Olson and Mead (1982, p. 26) concluded that "the largest, those 10 cm or more in length, almost certainly pertain to Dimetrodon, the only known member of the fauna large enough to have produced them." The purpose of this paper is to evaluate this hypothesis and to describe a new morphology of large coprolite from the Lower Permian of Texas. TMM refers to the Texas Memorial Museum collection at the Balcones Research Center of the University of Texas at Austin.

The majority of the large coprolites from the Early Permian of Texas derived from the Sid McAdams locality in the Vale Formation of Taylor County. This locality is at the base of the Vale Formation and was extensively collected by WPA crews in 1939 WPA crews in -1940 (Olson and Mead, 1982) . This area included three principal vertebrate bone localities as well as two specimens of tetrapod tracks (Olson and Mead, 1982; Lucas and Hunt, 2005) . Some of the coprolites from this area came from Olson and Mead's (1982) site 1, bed 3. However, varied preservation suggests that some coprolites came from at least two different localities. Olson and Mead (1982) reported that other coprolites came from the valley floor, which had been disturbed by plowing, and these may have all been catalogued into the University of California at Los Angeles collection.

The Sid McAdams collection contains several large coprolites, including TMM 30966-278 ( Fig. 1A-B ), TMM 30966-518 ( Fig. 1C-D) , TMM 30966-519 ( Fig. 1E-F) , TMM 30966-26 ( Fig. 1G-H ), TMM-30966 ( Fig. 1K ) and TMM 30966 ( Fig. 1L) .

TMM 30966-278 and TMM 30966-518 are broken ends of coprolites ( Fig. 1A-D) . They both preserve a broad section with a spiral whorl that terminates in a sub-acute tip. The broken ends exhibit a tapering below the spirals. In all these features the two coprolites are morphologically similar to Heteropolacopros texaniensis Hunt et al., 1998 (Hunt et al., 1998 . These specimens clearly pertain to this ichnotaxon, even though they are almost four times the size of previously recognized specimens. Hunt et al. (1988) suggested that Heteropolacopros texaniensis was produced by a xenacanth shark or possibly a lungfish.

TMM 30966-519 ( Fig. 1E-F) and TMM 30966-26 ( Fig. 1G-H ) are also broken ends of coprolites. Each of these also clearly shows a longitudinal spiral and thus must represent a fish with a spiral valve. One of two specimens labeled TMM 30966 ( Fig. 1K-M) is the most complete large coprolite from the Sid McAdams locality. These specimens do not exhibit spiraling, and they represent a new ichnotaxon described below.

Spiral coprolites can only be produced by an animal with a spiral valve, which must be a relatively primitive fish such as a xenacanth shark. Shark specimens from the Early Permian of Texas in the TMM collection include specimens (chrondrocrania, Meckelian cartilages) of individuals whose skulls must have been more than 20 cm in length, sharks large enough to have been viable sources of the large coprolites. Heteropolacopros texaniensis and other spiral coprolites are very common in the Early Permian and Late Triassic (Hunt et al., 1988

back_matter.text: 126 pears probable that most coprolites from redbeds of Permo-Triassic age are assignable to fish.Coprolites with no spiral structure are potentially representative of terrestrial faunal elements. This could include two specimens from the Sid McAdams locality and another from the Vale Formation. TMM 40339-12 is another large coprolite that does not exhibit any spiral structure ( Fig. 1I-J ). It is from the Arroyo Formation (Early Permian: middle Leonardian), West Table Mountain locality. These specimens could represent tetrapods.

Strophocopros, ichnogen. nov. Hunt and Lucas, 2005. Included species: Known only from the type species. Etymology: From the Greek strophos (twisted cord or rope), in allusion to the ropy surface texture of the coprolites, and kopros (feces).

Distribution: Early Permian of Texas (middle Leonardian). Diagnosis: Coprolite that differs from other ichnogenera in having a surface texture with a fibrous, ropy texture and in being over 10 cm in length.Discussion: This ichnogenus is currently only known from the middle Leonardian Vale Formation. We term the distinctive surface texture "strophic" from the Greek for twisted cord or rope. It is unclear what vertebrate yielded this ichnogenus. (Fig. 1L) .Diagnosis: As for genus. Description: TMM 30966 (Fig. 1K, M) is 144 mm long, 53 mm in maximum width and 25 mm in width. The coprolite is composed of two terminal portions that have tapering, rounded apices. These portions exhibit a distinctive linear surface texture reminiscent of rope (Fig. 1M ). In the middle portion of the coprolite the texture is more irregular Discussion: The referred specimen preserves the same strophic surface texture as the holotype, but it is different in overall morphology (Fig. 1L ). This coprolite is broken, and it is similar to the holotype in that several segments can be distinguished. The first segment has a linear strophic texture. The remainder of the coprolite consists of three tapering segments that are curled. This curling is distinct from the spiraling found in coprolites such as Heteropolacopros texaniensis and is found in the posterior portion of many coprolites.

BIBREF3.title: The Vale Formation (Lower Permian): its vertebrates and paleoecology
BIBREF3.raw_text: Olson, E. C. and Mead, J. G., 1982, The Vale Formation (Lower Permian): its ver- tebrates and paleoecology: Texas Memorial Museum Bulletin 29, 46 p.

TABREF0.text: ADRIAN P. HUNT AND SPENCER G. LUCAS New Mexico Museum of Natural History, 1801 Mountain Road NW, Albuquerque, NM 87104-1375 Abstract-Large coprolites from the Early Permian (middle Leonardian) Vale Formation have been assigned to Dimetrodon. Several of these coprolites are spiraled and represent large specimens of Heteropolacopros texaniensis. Other specimens are also spiraled. All spiraled coprolites represent fish, possibly xenacanth sharks. Two of the Vale specimens represent Strophocopros valensis ichnogen. et ichnosp. nov., which is characterized by a strophic (ropy) surface texture. Most of the coprolites from Permo-Triassic redbeds may have been produced by fish. Taylor County. G-H, TMM 30966-26, from the Sid McAdams locality, Vale Formation (Early Permian: middle Leonardian), Taylor County. I-J, TMM 40339-12, from the Arroyo Formation (Early Permian: middle Leonardian), West Table Mountain locality. K, M 30966, from the Sid McAdams locality, Vale Formation (Early Permian: middle Leonardian), Taylor County. L, 30966, from the Sid McAdams locality, Vale Formation (Early Permian: middle Leonardian), Taylor County. Scale bar is 2 cm.
